answers.author: Jeffrey Chapman
answers.text:
You might want to check out the "Employment Research" bulletin of the Upjohn Institute of July 2010.  It summarizes some of the research on this area and has many additional citations.


You might want to check out the "Employment Research" bulletin of the Upjohn Institute of July 2010.  It summarizes some of the research on this area and has many additional citations.

answers.author: John Doan
answers.text:
In a prior community, we had a partnership with the Economic Development Council to do business retention meetings. They would maintain a list of companies and contacts (generally employeers of 100 or more/or companies that the city didn't want to lose). They made the contact and someone from the EDB and a senior staff person (Administrator, Deputy, Community Devel. Director) would meet with them. It was pretty informal and focused on what's working? How's business? What challenges are you having? Is there anything we can do to help you? The EDB had expertise in workforce, taxation, capital, State regulation, and regional issues. The City rep. had expertise in permitting, transportation, traffic, utilities, marketing. It worked very well and people really appreciated the two different perspectives coming to visit. As a city person, it gave me a great insight to where business was at. Based on what we heard, we would often follow up with training or outreach to others. For example, when we kept hearing about employees who couldn't get to work, we worked with the transit providor to bring bus service.

They would maintain a list of companies and contacts (generally employeers of 100 or more/or companies that the city didn't want to lose). They made the contact and someone from the EDB and a senior staff person (Administrator, Deputy, Community Devel. Director) would meet with them. It was pretty informal and focused on what's working? How's business? What challenges are you having? Is there anything we can do to help you? The EDB had expertise in workforce, taxation, capital, State regulation, and regional issues. The City rep. had expertise in permitting, transportation, traffic, utilities, marketing. It worked very well and people really appreciated the two different perspectives coming to visit. As a city person, it gave me a great insight to where business was at. Based on what we heard, we would often follow up with training or outreach to others. For example, when we kept hearing about employees who couldn't get to work, we worked with the transit providor to bring bus service.

answers.author: Steve Art
answers.text:
You may want to check with the Sacramento Metro Chamber of Commerce.  They have a very good and effective program.  The contact is Matt Yancey

author: J. Warren
text: Does anyone have any experience developing a regional business retention and expansion program?  If so, what worked, what didn't, any ideas?  I am in the process of deciding whether or not this would be a good use of my organizations time and committment.  Also, if anyone has any information on the topic I would appreciate it.  Thanks
title: Regional Business Retention and Expansion Programs
